subject: Art & Design
title: Balance: Visual Weight Distribution
description: A micro-lesson that makes Balance: Visual Weight Distribution usable.

hook.text: A layout that feels 'off' usually has a balance problem. One side is visually heavier than the other.

buildup.text: Symmetrical balance mirrors elements on both sides. It feels stable, formal, and traditional.

discovery.text: Asymmetrical balance uses different-sized elements that still feel equilibrated â€” more dynamic, more modern.

twist.text: A small dark element can balance a large light one. Visual weight isn't about physical size alone.

climax.text: The squint test works here too: blur your eyes and check if the layout still feels evenly distributed.

punchline.text: Balance isn't about matching sides. It's about distributing attention.

quiz.question: How can a small element balance a larger one?
options: Through greater visual weight (darker color, higher contrast)
It can't â€” elements must be the same size
By using animation to draw attention
